I've had Beasts of Bermuda, for a while now. But only recently the past year really got into it, and I always find myself coming back now. 

The game has incredible customization options when it comes to skins, and the Devs are constantly adding new skins to different creatures to give even more variety to play around with. I've seen so many beautiful players, that make every skin you come across on another player feel unique. 

Gameplay is also fantastic, some hitboxes can be hard to learn and adjust to with the constant growing this game has. And while I think some hitboxes need a slight adjustment, overall PvP always feels fair and balanced. Abilities that every creature has feel unique in combat situations, and give every playable its own fighting and hunting style. I've found the balancing in this game is far superior to other Dinosaur Survival games, as it more is dependent on what you build and a players experience. Granted you will lose fights if its a bad matchup, but thats ok! Just reincarnate and try again, with a new build in the talent tree or learning from the experience. 

The trials in the game are a fun way to keep you occupied and moving around while you grow, and they are a bonus to your creature for the time spent doing them. Giving a better roll on possible inherits to your talent tree when your dino inevitably dies and you reincarnate it. And I love the fact you have multiple slots so you can play different things on the same server with your friends, and don't lose your creature completely after hours sunk into it like other Dinosaur Survival games. 

Weather system in the game is really good, with natural disasters that can happen from varying levels of flooding. To even tornados and dry storms that cause forest fires. Making it a fun and often exelerating experience trying to find shelter or high ground, as you watch the water coming up in a flood.

The community is great, both on Officials and Community Servers. I've had a few issues with other players, but nothing out of the normal from conflicting personalities and gameplay styles when it comes to online gaming. And when you want to find people to play with? Theirs the built in group finder, making it easy to find packmates or a herd to join. The map size is perfect for the amount of players, you can often find others whether to socialize or PvP. 

Updates are put out rather quickly, with every few months a new creature being added to the roster. Adding to the growing ecosystem and balancing of the roster. Glitches and bugs are often patched out extremely quickly once they are reported.

With even the Official Servers having set rules, makes the game feel more balanced and fair for every player. And the Mod team is incredibly responsive when you put in tickets in their Discord server, often very fast acting about issues you bring to them in tickets. 

The only two issues, I have with Beasts of Bermuda at this current moment in time. Is the newly implemented chat censors, that should have a toggle, not be automatic. And the fact sometimes the Mods don't agree on how rules should be percieved or handled. I've seen many times that Mods handling tickets, often don't deal out the same consequences or agree if something is a rulebreak. I believe the Mod team should put a more direct understanding on the rules we are given, rather then having it so vague and then having unfair punishments or no punishments delivered on situations. 

But overall I highly recommend Beasts of Bermuda, it's a very fun game solo or with friends. Many of the people you meet in the game are always more then willing to help new players, and explain mechanics. The global chat is a nice way to talk with everyone and make friends on servers, even when not directly playing together as the same creature.

Whether or not i should recommend Beasts of bermuda is a bit tricky, on one hand, out of the three big names in the dinosaur survival genre (The isle, path of titans and this game, beasts of bermuda)  it is without a doubt the one that feels the most like a finished game and has a lot of nice QOL that the other games don't.  

On the other it is somewhat difficult to get enjoyment out of due to endless growth meaning newer players or experienced players without an already started creature are kind of surpressed by people who put many hours and for lack of a better word dictate the actions of players around them,   this is particularly true on the official servers where clans are present and bully the smaller players around them

Since the last time i played the other servers (community servers/non officials), their populations have been less than ideal,  however if you are adamant on playing this game and are a dinosaur enthusiast you will likely have more fun than someone who isn't all that interested in dinosaurs whatsoever.

chill game, went across continents for a booty call and ended up tragically passing away before i got to tap, overall very fun to play with friends and honestly havent run into any issues with bans or roleplayers. very fun game gameplay loop and customization is nice.

Beast of Bermuda could improve by balancing its survival mechanics, optimizing performance, and offering clearer tutorials for new players. Adding new creatures like
Amargasaurus – A mid-sized sauropod with unique defensive sail spines, offering a tanky but not overpowered herbivore option.
Suchomimus – A lighter, fish-focused spinosaurid that could expand semi-aquatic gameplay without overlapping too much with bigger apex predators.
Deinonychus – A fast, coordinated pack-hunter that could bring more group-play mechanics and agile combat.
Pachyrhinosaurus – A bulky, defensive ceratopsian that isn’t just “another Trike,” offering alternative herd strategies.
Plesiosaurus (or another marine reptile) – To deepen the ocean biome and make sea gameplay more than just mosasaurs dominating the water.
Spinosaurus – A powerful semi-aquatic predator that dominates rivers and coastlines but is less effective on land than other apexes.
Carnotaurus – A fast, aggressive mid-tier predator with high burst speed and stamina efficiency, great for hit-and-run tactics.
Quetzalcoatlus – A massive flyer focused on long-distance travel, scouting, and territorial control, rather than pure combat.
Iguanodon – A versatile herd herbivore with both bipedal and quadrupedal movement styles for flexibility.
Finally, creating a better-designed map with balanced resources, varied biomes, and stronger landmarks would enhance exploration and overall playability.

I've had Beasts of Bermuda, for a while now. But only recently the past year really got into it, and I always find myself coming back now. 

The game has incredible customization options when it comes to skins, and the Devs are constantly adding new skins to different creatures to give even more variety to play around with. I've seen so many beautiful players, that make every skin you come across on another player feel unique. 

Gameplay is also fantastic, some hitboxes can be hard to learn and adjust to with the constant growing this game has. And while I think some hitboxes need a slight adjustment, overall PvP always feels fair and balanced. Abilities that every creature has feel unique in combat situations, and give every playable its own fighting and hunting style. I've found the balancing in this game is far superior to other Dinosaur Survival games, as it more is dependent on what you build and a players experience. Granted you will lose fights if its a bad matchup, but thats ok! Just reincarnate and try again, with a new build in the talent tree or learning from the experience. 

The trials in the game are a fun way to keep you occupied and moving around while you grow, and they are a bonus to your creature for the time spent doing them. Giving a better roll on possible inherits to your talent tree when your dino inevitably dies and you reincarnate it. And I love the fact you have multiple slots so you can play different things on the same server with your friends, and don't lose your creature completely after hours sunk into it like other Dinosaur Survival games. 

Weather system in the game is really good, with natural disasters that can happen from varying levels of flooding. To even tornados and dry storms that cause forest fires. Making it a fun and often exelerating experience trying to find shelter or high ground, as you watch the water coming up in a flood.

The community is great, both on Officials and Community Servers. I've had a few issues with other players, but nothing out of the normal from conflicting personalities and gameplay styles when it comes to online gaming. And when you want to find people to play with? Theirs the built in group finder, making it easy to find packmates or a herd to join. The map size is perfect for the amount of players, you can often find others whether to socialize or PvP. 

Updates are put out rather quickly, with every few months a new creature being added to the roster. Adding to the growing ecosystem and balancing of the roster. Glitches and bugs are often patched out extremely quickly once they are reported.

With even the Official Servers having set rules, makes the game feel more balanced and fair for every player. And the Mod team is incredibly responsive when you put in tickets in their Discord server, often very fast acting about issues you bring to them in tickets. 

The only two issues, I have with Beasts of Bermuda at this current moment in time. Is the newly implemented chat censors, that should have a toggle, not be automatic. And the fact sometimes the Mods don't agree on how rules should be percieved or handled. I've seen many times that Mods handling tickets, often don't deal out the same consequences or agree if something is a rulebreak. I believe the Mod team should put a more direct understanding on the rules we are given, rather then having it so vague and then having unfair punishments or no punishments delivered on situations. 

But overall I highly recommend Beasts of Bermuda, it's a very fun game solo or with friends. Many of the people you meet in the game are always more then willing to help new players, and explain mechanics. The global chat is a nice way to talk with everyone and make friends on servers, even when not directly playing together as the same creature.
It is a very fun and free game to play but the only down side is they lost a bit of devs and they arent giving up!

Whether or not i should recommend Beasts of bermuda is a bit tricky, on one hand, out of the three big names in the dinosaur survival genre (The isle, path of titans and this game, beasts of bermuda)  it is without a doubt the one that feels the most like a finished game and has a lot of nice QOL that the other games don't.  

On the other it is somewhat difficult to get enjoyment out of due to endless growth meaning newer players or experienced players without an already started creature are kind of surpressed by people who put many hours and for lack of a better word dictate the actions of players around them,   this is particularly true on the official servers where clans are present and bully the smaller players around them

Since the last time i played the other servers (community servers/non officials), their populations have been less than ideal,  however if you are adamant on playing this game and are a dinosaur enthusiast you will likely have more fun than someone who isn't all that interested in dinosaurs whatsoever.

Beasts of Bermuda is such a good game, I’ve sunk over a thousand hours into it. It’s fun and there’s always something to do, so I never really get bored. But a few things really frustrate me — there are tons of bugs, and once a tree killed my Rex 4.0. negative.review:
I don't often review games, but I am frustrated with the actions of the team behind this game. While I myself have not had issues, my friend who I frequently play with was banned without any warning... for mechanics built into the game. They were accused of statmaxxing due to having high comfort while starving. They were, however, under shelter which provides higher comfort and their stat went down once leaving the shelter area. The game has some jank terrain which allows you to gain this in places that don't really seem like it should. 

I will not be playing this game anymore since it was only enjoyable with my friend and wish I could get this refunded for them since they gifted it to me. Mods, please learn your own game mechanics before banning people. If you are banned you won't even know in game and just sit loading forever unless you go and ask the mods.

This game is the opposite of beginner friendly because the devs are lazy.
There are a bunch of rules that are in place even on official servers. When you're a new player and it's hard to tell what even is going on you're very vulnerable to accidently becoming a rulebreaker and getting banned.
These rules could be enforced with mechanics built into the game, however the devs prefer to run it like a 12 year old would run a minecraft server instead of actually coding how they wan't their game to behave.

Nobody wants to play a game full of cheaters run by developers that won't do anything about it and require video evidence and for you to open a ticket in their discord. Moderators and admins handle tickets on a case-by-case basis and often will show favoritism. Official servers crash constantly and most of the time, you'll need to ping an on-duty moderator who will then have to ping an admin to restart the server, which can take who-knows-how-long. On-duty moderators are also normally on Away status or Do Not Disturb. Server lag is pretty poor, and a lot of players experienced desynced gameplay and game lag that can be exploitable. The hitboxes on quite a few of the dinosaurs are absolutely ridiculous and are way off, and experienced players or hackers will exploit this heavily.

They just don't care about anything besides making money to make up for their losses. The game is extremely broken, often leading to extremely frustrating situations that would be otherwise avoidable entirely if the game would work as intended. This can often involve things like water sources and healing charcoal (used to heal illness) not working, which can of course lead to your dinosaur dying if you are so much as in the wrong place at the wrong time. You'll frequently get stuck on terrain and will be unable to climb correctly, often leading to painful falls that'd be avoidable if the terrain was properly done. You'll also frequently walk into and get stuck on invisible trees. Sometimes your dinosaur will be randomly teleported to a random location on the map, and moderators/admins will not do anything about any of your issues in the game without opening a ticket - and if you don't have evidence, then you can just save yourself the time because they won't do anything. They give known hackers the benefit of the doubt way beyond reasonable limits and refuse to do anything about clans in the game exploiting or using unfair gameplay methods to get ahead in the game basically because they don't want to be mean or exclusive. 

I don't recommend this game. Play something less frustrating, like maybe League of Legends or Dark Souls. The developers have something great, but instead of fixing their broken game with a multitude of easily fixable issues, they're squandering it because they want to add new dinosaurs and sell snake plushies to entice new game sales and extra revenue, to again, make up for their losses. They also just added a chat filter that censors all swear words and otherwise "inappropriate language." Apparently we can't handle bad language, so I don't think this game can handle a good review.
Exploiters galore, and the devs do not care. Do not waste your time.

After spending over 1,000 hours in Beasts of Bermuda, I can honestly say this game has so much potential — but it’s buried under layers of poor balance, inconsistent rules, and restrictive gameplay. I’ve put in enough time to see the best and worst this game has to offer, and while there are moments of real fun, they’re often overshadowed by frustration.

The core idea is great: growing your dinosaur, surviving the elements, managing comfort, and hunting or escaping others. When it works, it really works — those moments of tension and survival are what keep you coming back. But the official servers ruin much of that experience. There are so many rules that it feels more like a roleplay or PvE game than an open survival world. Seeing huge groups of herbivores and carnivores teaming up completely kills the atmosphere. Mix-packing and clan alliances are everywhere, making it almost impossible to grow or survive without running into unfair situations.

Community servers aren’t much better. Many of them have inconsistent admin decisions and rule sets so strict that killing the “wrong” player can get you banned or even forced to revive them. It’s wild — for a game built around survival and PvP, it often punishes you for simply playing the way the game was designed.

Balance is another major issue. Some dinosaurs are ridiculously overtuned, while others are left completely underpowered. It creates an uneven playing field where you’re almost forced to pick certain species just to stand a chance.

At times, Beasts of Bermuda feels more like a sandbox with rules than a survival game with freedom. And that’s a shame, because the mechanics, world design, and weather systems all have so much promise. I want to love this game — and in some ways, I do — but until the devs tackle the balance problems, rethink the rule-heavy server culture, and encourage real survival gameplay, it’s hard to fully recommend.

If you’re looking for a more authentic dinosaur survival experience, The Isle still does it better. But I genuinely hope Beasts of Bermuda can evolve into the game it’s meant to be, because the potential is absolutely there — it just needs the freedom to shine.
A lot of bugs and issues that they would rather work on cosmetics than fix a bug that teleports you from one end of the map to another

I’ve spent a good amount of time playing Beasts of Bermuda, and overall, it’s a fun and unique experience. The core gameplay — growing your dinosaur, surviving the environment, and interacting with others — can be genuinely enjoyable. The game has a strong foundation and a lot of potential to be something great.

However, the server experience really holds it back. The official servers are overloaded with restrictive rules that make the game feel more like a roleplay or PvE simulator than a true survival experience. You’ll often see huge groups of herbivores and carnivores playing together, which completely kills the natural tension of a survival game. Mix-packing and clan alliances are out of control, making it almost impossible to grow or progress without running into problems.

Community servers don’t always improve things either. Many enforce inconsistent or overly strict rules — kill the wrong player, and you can be banned or forced to revive them. It’s wild for what’s supposed to be a PvP dinosaur game.

On top of that, some dinosaurs are completely unbalanced, giving certain species unfair advantages and making the experience frustrating when you’re trying to play legitimately.

Personally, I find The Isle offers a more authentic dinosaur survival experience — you can play freely, hunt, and grow without being punished for natural gameplay. Beasts of Bermuda could easily reach that level if the community, balance, and server rules were refined. Right now, though, it feels more like a restricted sandbox than a true survival game.

Short Summary: 
- Growth gimmick lets players rule their server, determining if you get to play or not. 
The time investment/waste for progress in this game can range from 10-100+ hours while taking only about 5 minutes for that to be deleted. It's not even that fun once you start getting big as your stuck having to eat and drink for 90% of that time. No fun allowed.

- Official servers suffer from clans, typically a discord group that does everything it can to rule a server with sheer numbers. Typical Hackers. Very badly written and loop hole ridden rules. These rules allow mix packing in all cases but in immediate combat in short, so in the end your fate will likely still be sealed by a group of people playing as creatures not allowed to fight together.
The rules flaw is not having a strict fine line between mix packing and no mix packing.

vvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvv THE DETAILS vvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvv

#1 Issue: 1 player rules all 
- If someone manages to get big, it's over for anyone not friends with them so long as that playable has access to hunting the creature you play as.  If their semi snake, may as well log off for a few months or uninstall. (Your survival rate against largely grown playables will increase if you have friends though. Still bad balancing.)

#2 Issue: Designed to disrespect your investment and waste your time.
- With this games main gimmick being 'endless' growth, you can spend countless, and I mean 100+ hours into a single playable. However, more often then not, you'll die after investing 10-40 some hours on a playable to someone that simply got away with way larger growth.  

- -#2.1 Issue: The sacrafice trial system
- - - You put in an intense amount of effort to grow big and get your scores to 80-100% in all 3 categories? Well too bad, your inherits are unlikely to surpass what you would get at smaller growth breeding.

#3 Issue: Official Servers
Rules: 
They are made without a fine line between mix packing and no mix packing, punishing people that don't actively loop hole around the rules. What do I mean by this? Use of scouts, feeding other species out of combat, consuming food or heal plants around your different species buddies on going fight, sitting/sheltering by your bigger different species friend so if anyone tries to fight you, your bigger different species friends will engage in combat with them first, or if your different species friend and their foe sit down for 1 minute to regenerate resources, you can now take over the fight like tagging in and finish the person off without it counting as mix packing. This also applies if your friend dies, now you can immediately jump into the fight and finish the foe off. And it goes on like poison air bombing toxic shrooms on a herbivore as a flier/glider.

Clans: 
The above flaws with rules is where clans become an issue, utilizing loop holes or breaking rules that are hard to report someone for such as meshing or scouting. These people do not want a fair fight, they want to dominate and obliterate in numbers, and they will do what ever is in their power to take out their targeted victim be it tracking someones log in and log out locations, scouting them overall, and planning ambushes with all sorts of mega packing nonsense. Even hacking get's mixed into this such a teleporting a victim to a different part of the map.

Nobody wants to play a game full of cheaters run by developers that won't do anything about it and require video evidence and for you to open a ticket in their discord. Moderators and admins handle tickets on a case-by-case basis and often will show favoritism. Official servers crash constantly and most of the time, you'll need to ping an on-duty moderator who will then have to ping an admin to restart the server, which can take who-knows-how-long. On-duty moderators are also normally on Away status or Do Not Disturb. Server lag is pretty poor, and a lot of players experienced desynced gameplay and game lag that can be exploitable. The hitboxes on quite a few of the dinosaurs are absolutely ridiculous and are way off, and experienced players or hackers will exploit this heavily.

They just don't care about anything besides making money to make up for their losses. The game is extremely broken, often leading to extremely frustrating situations that would be otherwise avoidable entirely if the game would work as intended. This can often involve things like water sources and healing charcoal (used to heal illness) not working, which can of course lead to your dinosaur dying if you are so much as in the wrong place at the wrong time. You'll frequently get stuck on terrain and will be unable to climb correctly, often leading to painful falls that'd be avoidable if the terrain was properly done. You'll also frequently walk into and get stuck on invisible trees. Sometimes your dinosaur will be randomly teleported to a random location on the map, and moderators/admins will not do anything about any of your issues in the game without opening a ticket - and if you don't have evidence, then you can just save yourself the time because they won't do anything. They give known hackers the benefit of the doubt way beyond reasonable limits and refuse to do anything about clans in the game exploiting or using unfair gameplay methods to get ahead in the game basically because they don't want to be mean or exclusive. 

I don't recommend this game. Play something less frustrating, like maybe League of Legends or Dark Souls. The developers have something great, but instead of fixing their broken game with a multitude of easily fixable issues, they're squandering it because they want to add new dinosaurs and sell snake plushies to entice new game sales and extra revenue, to again, make up for their losses. They also just added a chat filter that censors all swear words and otherwise "inappropriate language." Apparently we can't handle bad language, so I don't think this game can handle a good review.

After spending over 1,000 hours in Beasts of Bermuda, I can honestly say this game has so much potential — but it’s buried under layers of poor balance, inconsistent rules, and restrictive gameplay. I’ve put in enough time to see the best and worst this game has to offer, and while there are moments of real fun, they’re often overshadowed by frustration.

The core idea is great: growing your dinosaur, surviving the elements, managing comfort, and hunting or escaping others. When it works, it really works — those moments of tension and survival are what keep you coming back. But the official servers ruin much of that experience. There are so many rules that it feels more like a roleplay or PvE game than an open survival world. Seeing huge groups of herbivores and carnivores teaming up completely kills the atmosphere. Mix-packing and clan alliances are everywhere, making it almost impossible to grow or survive without running into unfair situations.

Community servers aren’t much better. Many of them have inconsistent admin decisions and rule sets so strict that killing the “wrong” player can get you banned or even forced to revive them. It’s wild — for a game built around survival and PvP, it often punishes you for simply playing the way the game was designed.

Balance is another major issue. Some dinosaurs are ridiculously overtuned, while others are left completely underpowered. It creates an uneven playing field where you’re almost forced to pick certain species just to stand a chance.

At times, Beasts of Bermuda feels more like a sandbox with rules than a survival game with freedom. And that’s a shame, because the mechanics, world design, and weather systems all have so much promise. I want to love this game — and in some ways, I do — but until the devs tackle the balance problems, rethink the rule-heavy server culture, and encourage real survival gameplay, it’s hard to fully recommend.

If you’re looking for a more authentic dinosaur survival experience, The Isle still does it better. But I genuinely hope Beasts of Bermuda can evolve into the game it’s meant to be, because the potential is absolutely there — it just needs the freedom to shine.
A lot of bugs and issues that they would rather work on cosmetics than fix a bug that teleports you from one end of the map to another

I’ve spent a good amount of time playing Beasts of Bermuda, and overall, it’s a fun and unique experience. The core gameplay — growing your dinosaur, surviving the environment, and interacting with others — can be genuinely enjoyable. The game has a strong foundation and a lot of potential to be something great.

However, the server experience really holds it back. The official servers are overloaded with restrictive rules that make the game feel more like a roleplay or PvE simulator than a true survival experience. You’ll often see huge groups of herbivores and carnivores playing together, which completely kills the natural tension of a survival game. Mix-packing and clan alliances are out of control, making it almost impossible to grow or progress without running into problems.

Community servers don’t always improve things either. Many enforce inconsistent or overly strict rules — kill the wrong player, and you can be banned or forced to revive them. It’s wild for what’s supposed to be a PvP dinosaur game.

On top of that, some dinosaurs are completely unbalanced, giving certain species unfair advantages and making the experience frustrating when you’re trying to play legitimately.

Personally, I find The Isle offers a more authentic dinosaur survival experience — you can play freely, hunt, and grow without being punished for natural gameplay. Beasts of Bermuda could easily reach that level if the community, balance, and server rules were refined. Right now, though, it feels more like a restricted sandbox than a true survival game.

Short Summary: 
- Growth gimmick lets players rule their server, determining if you get to play or not. 
The time investment/waste for progress in this game can range from 10-100+ hours while taking only about 5 minutes for that to be deleted. It's not even that fun once you start getting big as your stuck having to eat and drink for 90% of that time. No fun allowed.

- Official servers suffer from clans, typically a discord group that does everything it can to rule a server with sheer numbers. Typical Hackers. Very badly written and loop hole ridden rules. These rules allow mix packing in all cases but in immediate combat in short, so in the end your fate will likely still be sealed by a group of people playing as creatures not allowed to fight together.
The rules flaw is not having a strict fine line between mix packing and no mix packing.

vvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvv THE DETAILS vvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvvv

#1 Issue: 1 player rules all 
- If someone manages to get big, it's over for anyone not friends with them so long as that playable has access to hunting the creature you play as.  If their semi snake, may as well log off for a few months or uninstall. (Your survival rate against largely grown playables will increase if you have friends though. Still bad balancing.)

#2 Issue: Designed to disrespect your investment and waste your time.
- With this games main gimmick being 'endless' growth, you can spend countless, and I mean 100+ hours into a single playable. However, more often then not, you'll die after investing 10-40 some hours on a playable to someone that simply got away with way larger growth.  

- -#2.1 Issue: The sacrafice trial system
- - - You put in an intense amount of effort to grow big and get your scores to 80-100% in all 3 categories? Well too bad, your inherits are unlikely to surpass what you would get at smaller growth breeding.

#3 Issue: Official Servers
Rules: 
They are made without a fine line between mix packing and no mix packing, punishing people that don't actively loop hole around the rules. What do I mean by this? Use of scouts, feeding other species out of combat, consuming food or heal plants around your different species buddies on going fight, sitting/sheltering by your bigger different species friend so if anyone tries to fight you, your bigger different species friends will engage in combat with them first, or if your different species friend and their foe sit down for 1 minute to regenerate resources, you can now take over the fight like tagging in and finish the person off without it counting as mix packing. This also applies if your friend dies, now you can immediately jump into the fight and finish the foe off. And it goes on like poison air bombing toxic shrooms on a herbivore as a flier/glider.

Clans: 
The above flaws with rules is where clans become an issue, utilizing loop holes or breaking rules that are hard to report someone for such as meshing or scouting. These people do not want a fair fight, they want to dominate and obliterate in numbers, and they will do what ever is in their power to take out their targeted victim be it tracking someones log in and log out locations, scouting them overall, and planning ambushes with all sorts of mega packing nonsense. Even hacking get's mixed into this such a teleporting a victim to a different part of the map.
